core_claim: Popsicles were invented in 1905 by an 11-year-old boy named Frank Epperson who accidentally left a mixture of powdered soda and water with a stirring stick outside overnight in freezing temperatures.
why_strange: One of America's favorite frozen treats was created entirely by accident by a child.

core_claim: Corn chips brand Fritos were invented by Charles Elmer Doolin in 1932 after he purchased a recipe for fried corn dough from a Mexican man at a gas station in San Antonio for $100.

supporting_details.seller: Mexican cook selling fried masa at gas station

source_citation: Smithsonian National Museum of American History; 'Fritos Pie: Stories, Recipes, and More' by Kaleta Doolin (2011)
why_strange: A billion-dollar snack empire began with a chance encounter and a $100 transaction at a gas station.

core_claim: Worcestershire sauce was accidentally created in 1837 when English chemists John Lea and William Perrins prepared a fermented fish sauce for Lord Sandys that was deemed too strong, then forgotten in their basement for years where it fermented further and became delicious.

supporting_details.client: Lord Marcus Sandys, former governor of Bengal

source_citation: Lea & Perrins company archives; 'A History of Worcestershire' by Worcestershire County Council
why_strange: One of the world's most distinctive condiments was essentially a failed recipe that was abandoned and then rediscovered after aging accidentally.

core_claim: The chocolate chip cookie was invented in 1938 by Ruth Wakefield at the Toll House Inn when she ran out of baker's chocolate and substituted broken pieces of Nestlé semi-sweet chocolate, expecting them to melt completely.

supporting_details.original_intention: To make chocolate cookies, expecting the pieces to melt

source_citation: Nestlé archives; 'Great American Cookies' by the Smithsonian Institution; New York Times historical archives
why_strange: America's favorite cookie resulted from a cooking miscalculation, not deliberate invention.

core_claim: Worcestershire sauce was accidentally created in the 1830s when two chemists abandoned a failed sauce experiment in a barrel—and rediscovered it months later as a flavorful condiment.

supporting_details.participants: John Wheeley Lea and William Henry Perrins, chemists
supporting_details.original_intent: To recreate a sauce from Bengal for Lord Sandys
supporting_details.accidental_fermentation: Sauce was too strong and stored in a cellar, where it fermented and mellowed

source_citation: Oxford Companion to Food (Alan Davidson); Lea & Perrins company history
why_strange: A global condiment was born from a spoiled experiment left to rot

core_claim: The croissant, often considered quintessentially French, actually originated in Austria and was inspired by a 17th-century battle with the Ottoman Empire.

supporting_details.participants: Viennese bakers; August Zang, Austrian artillery officer who opened a Viennese bakery in Paris
supporting_details.historical_event: Celebration of the defeat of the Ottomans at the Battle of Vienna; croissant shape mimics Islamic crescent

source_citation: The Oxford Companion to Food; Smithsonian Magazine, 'The Croissant’s Crescent-Shaped History'
why_strange: France's iconic pastry actually celebrates an Austrian military victory over the Turks

core_claim: The popsicle was invented by an 11-year-old boy who accidentally left a cup of powdered soda and a stirring stick outside on a freezing night in 1905.

supporting_details.original_invention: A mixture of powdered soda and water with a wooden stirrer
supporting_details.commercialization: Epperson patented it in 1923 as the 'Epsicle', later renamed 'Popsicle'

why_strange: A frozen treat beloved by millions was created by accident by a child

core_claim: Carrots were not originally orange; they were cultivated in various colors like purple, white, and yellow, and the iconic orange variety was specifically bred in the Netherlands.

supporting_details.reason: Likely developed by Dutch growers, possibly in tribute to the House of Orange, the Dutch royal family, or for improved agricultural traits.

source_citation: Stolarczyk, J. and B. Stolarczyk. 'The History of Carrots.' Horticultural Science (2018); University of Wisconsin-Madison, 'The History of Carrots' (hort.wisc.edu)
why_strange: Most people assume carrots have always been orange, making their colorful origins and specific breeding surprising.

core_claim: The famous Caesar salad was not invented in Italy or by someone named Caesar in ancient Rome, but rather in Tijuana, Mexico, by an Italian immigrant restaurateur.

supporting_details.circumstance: On a busy holiday weekend, with a depleted kitchen, Cardini improvised a salad from available ingredients.
supporting_details.original_ingredients: Romaine lettuce, olive oil, raw egg, croutons, Parmesan cheese, Worcestershire sauce, garlic, and black pepper

source_citation: Rosa, J. (2012). 'The History of Caesar Salad'. San Diego Historical Society; Julia Child's account (she visited the restaurant as a child and knew Cardini).
why_strange: The name and common perception suggest a European or Roman origin, not a spontaneous invention in Mexico.

core_claim: Ketchup did not originate as a tomato-based condiment but as a fermented fish sauce from Southeast Asia, arriving in Europe through trade routes.

supporting_details.location: Southeast Asia (specifically Fujian, China, where 'kê-chiap' or '鮭汁' referred to fermented fish brine), then Malaysia/Indonesia, then Europe.
supporting_details.original_ingredients: Fermented fish, brine, and spices; notably, no tomatoes.
supporting_details.evolution: British sailors brought it to Europe, where recipes evolved to include mushrooms, walnuts, or oysters, before tomatoes were widely adopted in the 19th century.

source_citation: Andrew F. Smith, 'Pure Ketchup: A History of America's National Condiment' (2001); Oxford English Dictionary (entry for 'ketchup').
why_strange: Modern ketchup is synonymous with tomatoes, making its ancient origin as a fish sauce highly unexpected.
